title: Lesson 10: Transport Across Membranes
moduleTitle: Cells as the Basis of Life
description: Understanding transport mechanisms across cell membranes including passive transport, active transport, osmosis, and bulk transport.
learningIntentions: Students can distinguish between passive transport (simple diffusion, facilitated diffusion, osmosis) and active transport.
Students can explain the role of membrane proteins in facilitated diffusion and active transport.
Students can describe bulk transport mechanisms (endocytosis and exocytosis).

successCriteria: I can define osmosis as the movement of water across a selectively permeable membrane.
I can explain why active transport requires energy and moves substances against their concentration gradient.

engagementHook.title: The Cell's Border Control
engagementHook.content: 'How does a glucose molecule get into your muscle cells after you eat, when the cell already has high glucose inside? Why can't water just rush in and burst the cell? And how does a white blood cell eat a bacterium? Today we explore how the membrane controls what enters and leaves through different transport strategies.'

keyConcepts.definition: No energy (ATP) required. Movement down concentration gradient (high to low).
Small, non-polar molecules (O₂, CO₂, lipids) pass through phospholipid bilayer.
Polar/charged molecules (glucose, ions) use channel or carrier proteins.
Diffusion of water across membrane (high water concentration/low solute to low water/high solute).
Requires ATP. Moves substances against concentration gradient (low to high). Uses carrier proteins (pumps).
For large molecules/particles. Endocytosis (brings in), Exocytosis (releases out).

misconceptions.misconception: Active transport means fast and passive means slow
misconceptions.correction: Speed varies; the difference is energy use and direction relative to gradient.

misconceptions.misconception: Osmosis is only about concentration of solute
misconceptions.correction: It's about water moving toward areas of lower water potential (higher solute), but emphasise water movement specifically.
Explicitly requires channel or carrier proteins—distinguish from simple diffusion.

items: Facilitated needs proteins; simple does not

contentSections.content: Two beakers separated by membrane. Side A: low solute (more water). Side B: high solute (less water). Arrow showing water movement from A to B. Cell in hypotonic solution (swelling) vs hypertonic (shrinking).
keyPoints: Water moves toward higher solute concentration
Lysis/cytolysis vs crenation in animal cells

contentSections.content: Endocytosis (membrane wrapping around particle → vesicle) vs Exocytosis (vesicle fusing with membrane → release).
contentSections.example: Phagocytosis by white blood cells (immune defence); secretion of digestive enzymes by pancreatic cells (exocytosis).

multipleChoice.question: Which process requires ATP to move molecules across the membrane?
multipleChoice.rationale: Energy requirement definition. Active transport moves substances against their concentration gradient using ATP.

multipleChoice.question: The movement of water molecules across a selectively permeable membrane from an area of high water concentration to low water concentration is called:
multipleChoice.rationale: Specific definition of osmosis - the diffusion of water across a membrane.

multipleChoice.question: A substance moves across the membrane down its concentration gradient using a carrier protein but does not use ATP. This is:
multipleChoice.rationale: Facilitated diffusion characteristics - uses proteins, no ATP, down gradient.

shortAnswer.question: Distinguish between simple diffusion and facilitated diffusion. (2 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Simple diffusion = direct movement through phospholipid bilayer, no proteins needed (small/non-polar molecules)
1 mark: Facilitated diffusion = requires channel or carrier proteins, for molecules that cannot cross lipid bilayer (polar/charged/large)
shortAnswer.commonError: Saying facilitated is 'helped by ATP' (confusing with active).

shortAnswer.question: Explain why active transport is necessary for root hair cells to absorb mineral ions from soil. (3 marks)
markingCriteria: 1 mark: Soil water has lower concentration of mineral ions than root hair cells (or concentration is against gradient)
1 mark: Therefore minerals must be moved against concentration gradient (from low to high)
1 mark: This requires energy (ATP) and specific carrier proteins (pumps)
shortAnswer.commonError: Describing diffusion instead; not mentioning concentration gradient.

definitions: Passive transport requires no energy; moves down concentration gradient (high to low).
Simple diffusion: small/non-polar through bilayer; Facilitated: uses proteins for polar/large molecules.
Osmosis: diffusion of water across membrane (toward higher solute).
Active transport: requires ATP; moves against gradient (low to high); uses pumps.
Endocytosis (cell eating/drinking) and exocytosis (secretion) move large materials.
keyPoints: Osmosis = water moves to higher solute concentration

shortAnswer: Simple diffusion is the movement of small, non-polar molecules (such as oxygen, carbon dioxide, and lipids) directly through the phospholipid bilayer without the help of proteins. Facilitated diffusion is the movement of polar, charged, or large molecules (such as glucose and ions) that cannot cross the lipid bilayer on their own. These molecules require channel proteins or carrier proteins to assist their movement across the membrane. Both processes move substances down their concentration gradient and do not require ATP.

Active transport is necessary for root hair cells because the concentration of mineral ions in the soil water is lower than inside the root hair cells. This means minerals must be absorbed against their concentration gradient, from an area of low concentration to high concentration. Moving substances against their gradient requires energy in the form of ATP. Additionally, specific carrier proteins (pumps) are needed to bind and transport these ions across the membrane. Without active transport, the plant would be unable to accumulate sufficient minerals for growth.
